hints_html: Don’t calculate the 100th power of A directly. Instead, diagonalize A = TDT-1 and then take the 100th power of that.
hints_latex:
Don't calculate the 100th power of \emph{A} directly. Instead,
diagonalize \emph{A = TDT}\textsuperscript{-1} and then take the 100th
power of that.
hints_raw: Don't calculate the 100th power of ''A'' directly. Instead, diagonalize ''A = TDT''<sup> -1</sup> and then take the 100th power of that.
sols_html:
We are not going to multiply A with itself a hundred times, at least not directly. Instead, we are going to diagonalize A first, because the 100th power of a diagonal matrix is much easier to calculate. Indeed, if D is the diagonal matrix corresponding to A (i.e. is a matrix with the eigenvalues of A on the diagonal), and if T is the transformation matrix of eigenvectors of A, then

\[\begin{aligned} A^n &= (TDT^{-1})^n \\ &= \underbrace{TDT^{-1} TDT^{-1} \cdots TDT^{-1}}_{n \text{ times}} \\ &= TD^nT^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

So let’s find D, T and T-1. We need the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A, so we calculate the roots of the characteristic polynomial \(\det(A - \lambda I)\):

\[\begin{aligned} \det(A - \lambda I) &= \left| \begin{array}{ccc} 1/2-\lambda & 0 & 1/3 \\ 0 & 1/2 - \lambda & 1/2 \\ 1/2 & 1/2 & 1/6 - \lambda \end{array} \right| \\ &= (\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)(\frac{1}{2} - \lambda)(\frac{1}{6} - \lambda) + 0 + 0 - \frac{1}{3}(\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)\frac{1}{2} - 0 - (\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{2} \\ &= (\frac12-\lambda)(\frac1{12}-\frac12\lambda-\frac16\lambda+\lambda^2-\frac16-\frac14) \\ &= (\frac12-\lambda)(\lambda^2-\frac23\lambda-\frac13) \\ &= (\frac12-\lambda)(\lambda+\frac13)(\lambda-1)\end{aligned}\]

And so the eigenvalues are 1/2, -1/3 and 1.

We compute an eigenvector for each eigenvalue using row reduction on the system \(A-\lambda I\).

For \(\lambda\) = 1 we have the system

\[\begin{aligned} A-I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1/2 & 0 & 1/3 \\ 0 & -1/2 & 1/2 \\ 1/2 & 1/2 & -5/6 \end{array}\right] \\ &\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & -2/3 \\ 0 & 1 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}\]

And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector [2, 3, 3].

For \(\lambda\) = 1/2 we have the system

\[\begin{aligned} A-(1/2)I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 1/3 \\ 0 & 0 & 1/2 \\ 1/2 & 1/2 & -1/3 \end{array}\right] \\ &\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}\]

And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector [1, -1, 0].

For \(\lambda\) = -1/3 we have the system

\[\begin{aligned} A+(1/3)I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 5/6 & 0 & 1/3 \\ 0 & 5/6 & 1/2 \\ 1/2 & 1/2 & 1/2 \end{array}\right] \\ &\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 5 & 0 & 2 \\ 0 & 5 & 3 \end{array}\right] \\ &\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 5 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}\]

And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector [2, 3, -5].

Using this basis of eigenvectors, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A = T \cdot D \cdot T^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

Where

\[\begin{aligned} D = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1/2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1/3 \end{array}\right] \quad T = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 & 1 & 2 \\ 3 & -1 & 3 \\ 3 & 0 & -5 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

We need now to compute the inverse of the matrix T. We obtain

\[\begin{aligned} T^{-1} = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\ 3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\ 3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

And so

\[\begin{aligned} A^n &= (T \cdot D \cdot T^{-1})^n \\ &= T \cdot D^n \cdot T^{-1} \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 & 1 & 2 \\ 3 & -1 & 3 \\ 3 & 0 & -5 \end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1^n & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & (1/2)^n & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & (-1/3)^n \end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\ 3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\ 3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8 \end{array}\right]\\ &= \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 & 2^{-n} & 2(-1/3)^n \\ 3 & -2^{-n} & (-1)^n 3^{1-n} \\ 3 & 0 & -5 (-1/3)^n \end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\ 3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\ 3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8 \end{array}\right] \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1/4 + (3/5)(1/2)^n + (3/20)(-1/3)^n & 1/4 - (2/5)(1/2)^n + (3/20)(-1/3)^n & 1/4 - (1/4)(-1/3)^n \\ 3/8 - (3/5)(1/2)^n + (9/40)(-1/3)^{n} & 3/8 + (2/5)(1/2)^n + (9/40)(-1/3)^{n} & 3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^{n} \\ 3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^n & 3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^n & 3/8 + (5/8)(-1/3)^n \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

So we can compute x100

\[\begin{aligned} x_{100} &= A^{100}x_0 \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1/4 + (3/5)2^{-100} + (3/20)3^{-100} & 1/4 - (2/5)2^{-100} + (3/20)3^{-100} & 1/4 - (1/4)3^{-100} \\ 3/8 - (3/5)2^{-100} + (9/40)3^{-100} & 3/8 + (2/5)2^{-100} + (9/40)3^{-100} & 3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} \\ 3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} & 3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} & 3/8 + (5/8)3^{-100} \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} 5\\ 5\\ 6 \end{array}\right] \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{c} 4 + (1/2)^{100} \\ 6 - (1/2)^{100} \\ 6 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}\]

As n becomes very large, xn approaches

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = \left[\begin{array}{c} 4\\ 6\\ 6 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We are not going to multiply \emph{A} with itself a hundred times, at
least not directly. Instead, we are going to diagonalize \emph{A} first,
because the 100th power of a diagonal matrix is much easier to
calculate. Indeed, if \emph{D} is the diagonal matrix corresponding to
\emph{A} (i.e. is a matrix with the eigenvalues of \emph{A} on the
diagonal), and if \emph{T} is the transformation matrix of eigenvectors
of \emph{A}, then

\begin{align*}
A^n &= (TDT^{-1})^n \\
&= \underbrace{TDT^{-1} TDT^{-1} \cdots TDT^{-1}}_{n \text{ times}} \\
&= TD^nT^{-1}
\end{align*}

So let's find \emph{D}, \emph{T} and \emph{T}\textsuperscript{-1}. We
need the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of \emph{A}, so we calculate the
roots of the characteristic polynomial $\det(A - \lambda I)$:

\begin{align*}
\det(A - \lambda I) &= \left| \begin{array}{ccc}
1/2-\lambda & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & 1/2 - \lambda & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & 1/6 - \lambda
\end{array} \right| \\
&= (\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)(\frac{1}{2} - \lambda)(\frac{1}{6} - \lambda) + 0 + 0 - \frac{1}{3}(\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)\frac{1}{2} - 0 - (\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{2} \\
&= (\frac12-\lambda)(\frac1{12}-\frac12\lambda-\frac16\lambda+\lambda^2-\frac16-\frac14) \\
&= (\frac12-\lambda)(\lambda^2-\frac23\lambda-\frac13) \\
&= (\frac12-\lambda)(\lambda+\frac13)(\lambda-1)
\end{align*} And so the eigenvalues are 1/2, -1/3 and 1.

We compute an eigenvector for each eigenvalue using row reduction on the
system $A-\lambda I$.

For $\lambda$ = 1 we have the system

\begin{align*}
A-I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
-1/2 & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & -1/2 & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & -5/6
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & -2/3 \\
0 & 1 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right] 
\end{align*} And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector {[}2,
3, 3{]}.

For $\lambda$ = 1/2 we have the system

\begin{align*}
A-(1/2)I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & 0 & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & -1/3
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right] 
\end{align*} And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector {[}1,
-1, 0{]}.

For $\lambda$ = -1/3 we have the system

\begin{align*}
A+(1/3)I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
5/6 & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & 5/6 & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & 1/2
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
5 & 0 & 2 \\
0 & 5 & 3
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
0 & 5 & 3 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right] 
\end{align*} And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector {[}2,
3, -5{]}.

Using this basis of eigenvectors, we have that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
A = T \cdot D \cdot T^{-1}
\end{align*} Where

\begin{align*}
D = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1/2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -1/3
\end{array}\right] \quad T = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 2 \\
3 & -1 & 3 \\
3 & 0 & -5
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

We need now to compute the inverse of the matrix \emph{T}. We obtain

\begin{align*}
T^{-1} = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\
3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\
3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

And so

\begin{align*}
A^n &= (T \cdot D \cdot T^{-1})^n \\
&= T \cdot D^n \cdot T^{-1} \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 2 \\
3 & -1 & 3 \\
3 & 0 & -5
\end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1^n & 0 & 0 \\
0 & (1/2)^n & 0 \\
0 & 0 & (-1/3)^n
\end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\
3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\
3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8
\end{array}\right]\\
&= \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 2^{-n} & 2(-1/3)^n \\
3 & -2^{-n} & (-1)^n 3^{1-n} \\
3 & 0 & -5 (-1/3)^n
\end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\
3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\
3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8
\end{array}\right] \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/4 + (3/5)(1/2)^n + (3/20)(-1/3)^n & 1/4 - (2/5)(1/2)^n + (3/20)(-1/3)^n & 1/4 - (1/4)(-1/3)^n \\
3/8 - (3/5)(1/2)^n + (9/40)(-1/3)^{n} & 3/8 + (2/5)(1/2)^n + (9/40)(-1/3)^{n} & 3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^{n} \\
3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^n & 3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^n & 3/8 + (5/8)(-1/3)^n
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

So we can compute \emph{x}\textsubscript{100}

\begin{align*}
x_{100} &= A^{100}x_0 \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/4 + (3/5)2^{-100} + (3/20)3^{-100} & 1/4 - (2/5)2^{-100} + (3/20)3^{-100} & 1/4 - (1/4)3^{-100} \\
3/8 - (3/5)2^{-100} + (9/40)3^{-100} & 3/8 + (2/5)2^{-100} + (9/40)3^{-100} & 3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} \\
3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} & 3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} & 3/8 + (5/8)3^{-100}
\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c}
5\\
5\\
6
\end{array}\right] \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{c}
4 + (1/2)^{100} \\
6 - (1/2)^{100} \\
6
\end{array}\right] 
\end{align*}

As \emph{n} becomes very large, \emph{x\textsubscript{n}} approaches

\begin{align*}
\lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = \left[\begin{array}{c}
4\\
6\\
6
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We are not going to multiply ''A'' with itself a hundred times, at least not directly. Instead, we are going to diagonalize ''A'' first, because the 100th power of a diagonal matrix is much easier to calculate. Indeed, if ''D'' is the diagonal matrix corresponding to ''A'' (i.e. is a matrix with the eigenvalues of ''A'' on the diagonal), and if ''T'' is the transformation matrix of eigenvectors of ''A'', then

:<math> \begin{align}
A^n &= (TDT^{-1})^n \\
&= \underbrace{TDT^{-1} TDT^{-1} \cdots TDT^{-1}}_{n \text{ times}} \\
&= TD^nT^{-1}
\end{align}
</math>

So let's find ''D'', ''T'' and ''T''<sup> -1</sup>. We need the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of ''A'', so we calculate the roots of the characteristic polynomial <math>\det(A - \lambda I)</math>:
:<math>
\begin{align}
\det(A - \lambda I) &= \left| \begin{array}{ccc}
1/2-\lambda & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & 1/2 - \lambda & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & 1/6 - \lambda
\end{array} \right| \\
&= (\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)(\frac{1}{2} - \lambda)(\frac{1}{6} - \lambda) + 0 + 0 - \frac{1}{3}(\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)\frac{1}{2} - 0 - (\frac{1}{2}-\lambda)\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{2} \\
&= (\frac12-\lambda)(\frac1{12}-\frac12\lambda-\frac16\lambda+\lambda^2-\frac16-\frac14) \\
&= (\frac12-\lambda)(\lambda^2-\frac23\lambda-\frac13) \\
&= (\frac12-\lambda)(\lambda+\frac13)(\lambda-1)
\end{align}
</math>
And so the eigenvalues are 1/2, -1/3 and 1.

We compute an eigenvector for each eigenvalue using row reduction on the system <math>A-\lambda I</math>.

For &lambda; = 1 we have the system
:<math>\begin{align}
A-I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
-1/2 & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & -1/2 & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & -5/6
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & -2/3 \\
0 & 1 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right] \\
\end{align}</math>
And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector [2, 3, 3].

For &lambda; = 1/2 we have the system
:<math>\begin{align}
A-(1/2)I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & 0 & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & -1/3
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right] \\
\end{align}</math>
And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector [1, -1, 0].

For &lambda; = -1/3 we have the system
:<math>\begin{align}
A+(1/3)I &= \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
5/6 & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & 5/6 & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & 1/2
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
5 & 0 & 2 \\
0 & 5 & 3
\end{array}\right] \\
&\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
0 & 5 & 3 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right] \\
\end{align}</math>
And so this eigenspace is spanned by the eigenvector [2, 3, -5].

Using this basis of eigenvectors, we have that
:<math>\displaystyle
A = T \cdot D \cdot T^{-1}
</math>
Where
:<math>
D = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1/2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -1/3
\end{array}\right] \quad T = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 2 \\
3 & -1 & 3 \\
3 & 0 & -5
\end{array}\right]
</math>

We need now to compute the inverse of the matrix ''T''. We obtain
:<math>
T^{-1} = \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\
3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\
3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8
\end{array}\right]
</math>

And so
:<math>\begin{align}
A^n &= (T \cdot D \cdot T^{-1})^n \\
&= T \cdot D^n \cdot T^{-1} \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 2 \\
3 & -1 & 3 \\
3 & 0 & -5
\end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1^n & 0 & 0 \\
0 & (1/2)^n & 0 \\
0 & 0 & (-1/3)^n
\end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\
3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\
3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8
\end{array}\right]\\
&= \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 2^{-n} & 2(-1/3)^n \\
3 & -2^{-n} & (-1)^n 3^{1-n} \\
3 & 0 & -5 (-1/3)^n
\end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/8 & 1/8 & 1/8 \\
3/5 & -2/5 & 0 \\
3/40 & 3/40 & -1/8
\end{array}\right] \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/4 + (3/5)(1/2)^n + (3/20)(-1/3)^n & 1/4 - (2/5)(1/2)^n + (3/20)(-1/3)^n & 1/4 - (1/4)(-1/3)^n \\
3/8 - (3/5)(1/2)^n + (9/40)(-1/3)^{n} & 3/8 + (2/5)(1/2)^n + (9/40)(-1/3)^{n} & 3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^{n} \\
3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^n & 3/8 - (3/8)(-1/3)^n & 3/8 + (5/8)(-1/3)^n
\end{array}\right]
\end{align}</math>

So we can compute ''x''<sub>100</sub>
:<math>\begin{align}
x_{100} &= A^{100}x_0 \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1/4 + (3/5)2^{-100} + (3/20)3^{-100} & 1/4 - (2/5)2^{-100} + (3/20)3^{-100} & 1/4 - (1/4)3^{-100} \\
3/8 - (3/5)2^{-100} + (9/40)3^{-100} & 3/8 + (2/5)2^{-100} + (9/40)3^{-100} & 3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} \\
3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} & 3/8 - (3/8)3^{-100} & 3/8 + (5/8)3^{-100}
\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c}
5\\
5\\
6
\end{array}\right] \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{c}
4 + (1/2)^{100} \\
6 - (1/2)^{100} \\
6
\end{array}\right] \\
\end{align}</math>

As ''n'' becomes very large, ''x<sub>n</sub>'' approaches
:<math>
\lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = \left[\begin{array}{c}
4\\
6\\
6
\end{array}\right]
</math>
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} A = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1/2 & 0 & 1/3 \\ 0 & 1/2 & 1/2 \\ 1/2 & 1/2 & 1/6 \end{array}\right] \qquad \text{and let}\qquad x_0 = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 5\\ 5\\ 6 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Let xn = Anx0. Then find x100 = A100x0. What happens to xn as n becomes very large?

Note: there is a typo in the exam, it is written xn = Anxn instead of xn = Anx0
statement_latex:
Let

\begin{align*}
A = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1/2 & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & 1/2 & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & 1/6
\end{array}\right] \qquad \text{and let}\qquad x_0 = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
5\\
5\\
6
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*} Let \emph{x}\textsubscript{\emph{n}} =
\emph{A}\textsuperscript{\emph{n}}\emph{x}\textsubscript{0}. Then find
\emph{x}\textsubscript{100} =
\emph{A}\textsuperscript{100}\emph{x}\textsubscript{0}. What happens to
\emph{x}\textsubscript{\emph{n}} as \emph{n} becomes very large?

\textbf{Note: there is a typo in the exam, it is written
\emph{x}\textsubscript{\emph{n}} =
\emph{A}\textsuperscript{\emph{n}}\emph{x}\textsubscript{\emph{n}}
instead of \emph{x}\textsubscript{\emph{n}} =
\emph{A}\textsuperscript{\emph{n}}\emph{x}\textsubscript{0}}
statement_raw:
Let
:<math>
A = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
1/2 & 0 & 1/3 \\
0 & 1/2 & 1/2 \\
1/2 & 1/2 & 1/6
\end{array}\right] \qquad \text{and let}\qquad x_0 = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
5\\
5\\
6
\end{array}\right]
</math>
Let ''x''<sub>''n''</sub> = ''A''<sup>''n''</sup>''x''<sub>0</sub>. Then find ''x''<sub>100</sub> = ''A''<sup>100</sup>''x''<sub>0</sub>. What happens to ''x''<sub>''n''</sub> as ''n'' becomes very large?

'''Note: there is a typo in the exam, it is written ''x''<sub>''n''</sub> = ''A''<sup>''n''</sup>''x''<sub>''n''</sub> instead of ''x''<sub>''n''</sub> = ''A''<sup>''n''</sup>''x''<sub>0</sub>'''
